Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Untangling history and ecology to reconstruct the assembly of an iconic avifauna
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will develop and test a conceptual framework for understanding the assembly, and species composition, of mixed-species flocks of birds by studying the roles of evolutionary history and ecological processes of flocks in the Solomon Islands. The birds of the Solomon Islands have long served as a natural laboratory for the development of community assembly theory. The results of this research will form the basis of understanding in more complex natural systems. By understanding community assembly history, it becomes possible to search for the effects of that history on attributes of contemporary systems. For example, if the order of species arrival into a community influences the functional roles of species in a community, it may be possible to use community assembly history to make predictions about the ecology of contemporary systems. Such a connection would suggest that other attributes of communities, such as stability or resistance to extinction, might be influenced by assembly history. Additionally, the research will form the basis of in-country training for local communities to develop skills necessary to survey biodiversity, build an appreciation for the global significance of the Archipelago's diversity, will contribute to a growing body of open access educational materials tailored to the Solomon Islands, and will train a student in the New York City area in statistical and morphological methods.

In order to reconstruct the assembly history of mixed-species foraging flocks in the Solomon Archipelago, this research will use next generation sequencing of ultraconserved elements from fresh tissues and ancient DNA. Historical biogeography and demography will be used to reveal the sequence of colonization, ancestral population sizes, and gene flow between populations for six lineages of birds that form the nucleus of mixed-species flocks in the Solomon Islands. These data will be related to morphological and ecological data to test for the presence of a signal of island assembly history on contemporary morphology and ecology. While assembly history may appear stochastic at ecological timescales, it assumes a degree of predictability at evolutionary scales. This study will test whether these predictable larger scale patterns influence the ecology of communities. Ultimately, by reconstructing the processes that guide community assembly, it may not only be possible to begin to characterize the history of biotas, but potentially to make predictive statements about ecology based on historical reconstructions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Achievements:

This project aimed to establish a model system and approach for understanding the impacts of alternate community assembly histories on the contemporary ecology of natural systems. While it has been demonstrated that alternate histories (e.g., different orders of arrival into a community) can impact important ecosystem functions in laboratory experiments, the ability of these alternate histories to have lasting impacts in the natural world is largely unknown. Should such a relationship be found, it would have broad implications for the necessity of incorporating biogeographic history into ecosystem ecology. Such a finding would also suggest that aspects of contemporary ecology may be predictable, based on the assembly history of communities.

In order to test the theory that alternate assembly histories can impact ecological communities in natural systems, this project combined behavioral, morphological, and genomic data. Behavioral data are time-consuming and difficult to collect, so a morphological proxy for these data would be of broad general interest for examining behavior at temporal and spatial scales not suitable to direct observation. While morphology is often used this way, there is limited empirical support for such a relationship, and it is unclear how sensitive that relationship may be to evolutionary processes, such as rapid adaptation. We combined behavioral observations and specimen-based morphometric analyses of flocking birds across the Solomon Archipelago to test whether shifts in morphology are correlated with shifts in foraging behavior in island birds. We demonstrate that, despite the likely rapid adaptive change following island colonization, shifts in morphology are correlated to shifts in behavior across taxonomic scales. Having established the relationship between morphology and behavior for this system, we began to use morphology and genomics to explore the impacts of alternate community assembly histories on behavioral ecology at broader spatial and temporal scales. Using ultraconserved elements, we are establishing the relative order of arrival of flocking species to each island, and comparing the biogeographic histories of the groups to establish whether there are different community assembly histories across the archipelago. These genomic and morphological data provide the information necessary to test for the persistence of priority effects across evolutionary time in a natural system. In addition to establishing a link between morphology and ecology, we have discovered that the relationships between clades on Pleistocene landmasses vary across groups, suggesting that rather than a consistent biogeographic history, there has been variation in the colonization and assembly history across groups, and variation in the relative timing of arrival of different species to different islands. This finding suggests the Solomon Archipelago is an ideal natural laboratory for the continued development of methods to reconstruct community assembly history and to test for ecological impacts of alternate histories on contemporary ecology.

 

Broader Impacts:

This project engaged high school students in collections-based research, developed educational materials, and directly engaged Solomon Islands landowners, scientists, and conservation practitioners. Two students were mentored through the science research mentoring program (SRMP) at the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH). SRMP seeks to engage students of historically underrepresented groups in museum-based science. These students were trained to measure morphology on museum study skins, and were guided in systematic literature review and hypothesis-testing through bi-weekly meetings over the course of the academic year; the data collected will be the basis of an academic publication testing the hypothesis that dispersal has had a greater inhibitory effect on diversification rates in continental systems than in island systems. In addition to direct mentorship, this project will result in the development of an open-access teaching module Where is the World’s Biodiversity? This module is being developed with the Network of Conservation Educators and Practitioners at AMNH and will ultimately be peer-reviewed and publicly disseminated through their website and teacher training activities. Finally, the Solomon Islands are undergoing rapid habitat modification as a result of unsustainable resource extraction, which is threatening their globally-significant biodiversity. The fieldwork conducted for this project engaged Solomon Islands landowners, scientistis, and conservation practitioners. Behavioral data were collected on three islands: Kolombangara, Choiseul, and Makira, each of which have globally-significant bird communities. This fieldwork afforded the opportunity to train local landowners in field biology methods, including a conservation ranger for the Kolombangara Island Biodiversity Conservation Association, and provided an opportunity to strengthen the appreciation of the potential for these unique birds to serve as conservation tools for landowners who are actively pursuing alternate options to resource extraction for sustainable development within their communities on Choiseul and Makira. On Makira, this work engaged the son of a chief who expressed interest in developing a conservation program on their customary land, which is increasingly surrounded by active logging concessions. Based on this interest, the co-PI of this project began engaging with the Solomon Islands Community Conservation Partnership to explore potential collaborations with SICCP as a first step toward exploring conservation potential on Makira.
